Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial on the Influence of Physician and Patient Race on Surgical Decision-Making

Participants.evidence: Participants were recruited from various U.S. medical centers

Intervention.evidence: videos of SPs randomized to black or white

Objective.evidence: This study investigates whether physician and standardized patient (SP) race in videos influence surgeon decision-making.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the change in risk estimation for major surgical complications, measured immediately after video viewing.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was not applicable as participants viewed videos.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 113 surgeons (38 practicing, 75 trainees) participated

Result_Outcome.evidence: The percentage change in risk estimates was not significantly related to patient race (p = 0.11) or surgeon race (p = 0.52).
